sentences.text: II.

rhetClass.text: II.

sentences.text: Service Connection

rhetClass.text: Service Connection

sentences.text: A Veteran is entitled to VA disability compensation if there is a disability resulting from personal injury suffered or disease contracted in the line of duty in active service, or for aggravation of a preexisting injury suffered or disease contracted in the line of duty in active service.

rhetClass.text: A Veteran is entitled to VA disability compensation if there is a disability resulting from personal injury suffered or disease contracted in the line of duty in active service, or for aggravation of a preexisting injury suffered or disease contracted in the line of duty in active service.

sentences.text: Generally, to establish a right to compensation for a present disability, a Veteran must show: (1) a present disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service, the so-called "nexus" requirement.

rhetClass.text: Generally, to establish a right to compensation for a present disability, a Veteran must show: (1) a present disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service, the so-called "nexus" requirement.

sentences.text: Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004).

rhetClass.text: Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004).

sentences.text: Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all of the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that a disease was incurred in service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all of the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that a disease was incurred in service.

sentences.text: Under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(b), claims for chronic diseases enumerated in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a) benefit from a relaxed evidentiary standard.

rhetClass.text: Under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(b), claims for chronic diseases enumerated in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a) benefit from a relaxed evidentiary standard.

sentences.text: See Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331, 1339 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

rhetClass.text: See Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331, 1339 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

sentences.text: When a chronic disease is established during active service, then subsequent manifestations of the same chronic disease at any later date, however remote, will be entitled to service connection, unless clearly attributable to intercurrent causes.

rhetClass.text: When a chronic disease is established during active service, then subsequent manifestations of the same chronic disease at any later date, however remote, will be entitled to service connection, unless clearly attributable to intercurrent causes.

sentences.text: In order to establish the existence of a chronic disease in service, the evidence must show a combination of manifestations sufficient to identify the disease entity, and sufficient observation to establish chronicity at the time, as distinguished from merely isolated findings or a diagnosis including the word "chronic."

rhetClass.text: In order to establish the existence of a chronic disease in service, the evidence must show a combination of manifestations sufficient to identify the disease entity, and sufficient observation to establish chronicity at the time, as distinguished from merely isolated findings or a diagnosis including the word "chronic."

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: Thus, the mere manifestation during service of potentially relevant symptoms, such as joint pain for degenerative joint disease, does not establish a chronic disease at that time unless the identity of the disease is established and its chronicity may not be legitimately questioned.

rhetClass.text: Thus, the mere manifestation during service of potentially relevant symptoms, such as joint pain for degenerative joint disease, does not establish a chronic disease at that time unless the identity of the disease is established and its chronicity may not be legitimately questioned.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: If chronicity in service is not established, then a showing of continuity of symptoms after discharge is required to support the claim.

rhetClass.text: If chronicity in service is not established, then a showing of continuity of symptoms after discharge is required to support the claim.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: The Federal Circuit, however, has clarified that this notion of continuity of symptomatology since service under  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(b), which is an alternative means of establishing the required nexus or linkage between current disability and service, only applies to conditions identified as chronic under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a).

rhetClass.text: The Federal Circuit, however, has clarified that this notion of continuity of symptomatology since service under  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(b), which is an alternative means of establishing the required nexus or linkage between current disability and service, only applies to conditions identified as chronic under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a).

sentences.text: Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

rhetClass.text: Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

sentences.text: While peripheral neuropathy is not a disease specifically enumerated as a chronic disease under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a), organic diseases of the nervous system are listed as disabilities subject to presumptive service connection.

rhetClass.text: While peripheral neuropathy is not a disease specifically enumerated as a chronic disease under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309(a), organic diseases of the nervous system are listed as disabilities subject to presumptive service connection.

sentences.text: Accordingly, service connection may be granted on a presumptive basis for peripheral neuropathy if it is shown to be manifest to a degree of 10 percent or more within one year following the Veteran's separation from active military service.

rhetClass.text: Accordingly, service connection may be granted on a presumptive basis for peripheral neuropathy if it is shown to be manifest to a degree of 10 percent or more within one year following the Veteran's separation from active military service.

sentences.text: Under section 3.310(a) of VA regulations, service connection may be established on a secondary basis for a disability which is proximately due to or the result of service-connected disease or injury.

rhetClass.text: Under section 3.310(a) of VA regulations, service connection may be established on a secondary basis for a disability which is proximately due to or the result of service-connected disease or injury.

sentences.text: Establishing service connection on a secondary basis requires evidence sufficient to show: (1) a current disability; (2) a service-connected disability; and (3) a nexus between the current disability and the service-connected disability.

rhetClass.text: Establishing service connection on a secondary basis requires evidence sufficient to show: (1) a current disability; (2) a service-connected disability; and (3) a nexus between the current disability and the service-connected disability.

sentences.text: See Wallin v. West, 11 Vet. App. 509, 512 (1988).

rhetClass.text: See Wallin v. West, 11 Vet. App. 509, 512 (1988).

sentences.text: As to the third Wallin element, the current disability may be either (a) proximately caused by or (b) proximately aggravated by a service-connected disability.

rhetClass.text: As to the third Wallin element, the current disability may be either (a) proximately caused by or (b) proximately aggravated by a service-connected disability.

sentences.text: Allen v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 439, 448 (1995) (en banc).

rhetClass.text: Allen v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 439, 448 (1995) (en banc).

sentences.text: Where a service-connected disability aggravates a non-service-connected condition, a Veteran may be compensated for the degree of disability (but only that degree) over and above the degree of disability existing prior to the aggravation.

rhetClass.text: Where a service-connected disability aggravates a non-service-connected condition, a Veteran may be compensated for the degree of disability (but only that degree) over and above the degree of disability existing prior to the aggravation.

sentences.text: 7 Vet. App. at 448.

rhetClass.text: 7 Vet. App. at 448.

sentences.text: Any increase in severity of a nonservice-connected disease or injury that is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury, and not due to the natural progress of the nonservice-connected disease, will be service connected.

rhetClass.text: Any increase in severity of a nonservice-connected disease or injury that is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury, and not due to the natural progress of the nonservice-connected disease, will be service connected.

sentences.text: VA will not concede a nonservice-connected disease or injury was aggravated by a service-connected disease or injury unless the baseline level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury is established by medical evidence created before the onset of aggravation or by the earliest medical evidence created at any time between the onset of aggravation and the receipt of medical evidence establishing the current level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury.

rhetClass.text: VA will not concede a nonservice-connected disease or injury was aggravated by a service-connected disease or injury unless the baseline level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury is established by medical evidence created before the onset of aggravation or by the earliest medical evidence created at any time between the onset of aggravation and the receipt of medical evidence establishing the current level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury.

rhetClass.text: A GAF of 21 to 30 is defined as behavior considerably influenced by delusions or hallucinations or serious impairment in communication or judgment (e.g., sometimes incoherent, acts grossly inappropriate, suicidal preoccupation) or an inability to function in almost all areas (e.g., stays in bed all day, no job, home or friends).

sentences.text: A GAF of 31 to 40 is indicative of some impairment in reality testing or communication (e.g., speech is at times illogical, obscure, or irrelevant) or any major impairment in several areas, such as work or school, family relations, judgment, thinking or mood (e.g., depressed man avoids friends, neglects family, and is unable to work; child frequently beats up younger children, is defiant at home, and is failing at school).

sentences.text: A GAF of 41 to 50 is indicative of serious symptoms (e.g., suicidal ideation, severe obsessional rituals, frequent shoplifter) or any serious impairment in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., no friends, unable to keep a job).
